conbody.p: Topics are generally either learningContent or learningAssessment.

In the topic prolog, include an author credit if you create a topic or significantly add to an existing topic. You can also include a web link to your site:<prolog> <author>Sharon Burton</author> <author href="http://www.scriptorium.com">Sarah O'Keefe, Scriptorium</author> <critdates> <created date="2015-04-28"/> </critdates> </prolog>
If you add to an existing topic, keep the original contributor at the top of the list and add your name in a separate author element.
Include a <created> element or add a <revised> element with the appropriate date. Use YYYY-MM-DD format for the date.

section.title: Learning module structure
section.p:
Each module should have a container topic, which provides the following:
A list of objectives for the module, using lcObjectives: <lcObjectives> <lcObjectivesGroup> <lcObjective>What kind of topics exist in DITA</lcObjective> <lcObjective>What information goes in different types of topics</lcObjective> <lcObjective>What are constraints and specialization?</lcObjective> </lcObjectivesGroup> </lcObjectives>
An estimated duration for the module, using lcDuration (provide a value in minutes):<lcDuration> <lcTime value="30"/> </lcDuration>
An overview of the module, using lcIntro
A list of additional reading resources, using related-links. Be sure to code external web links with the appropriate format (usually html or pdf) and scope (external):<link href="http://www.oxygenxml.com/dita/styleguide/webhelp-feedback/#Artefact/c_Syntax_and_Markup.html" format="html" scope="external"> <linktext>DITA Style Guide, Chapter 3, Syntax and Markup</linktext> </link>
Inside the overview container, provide learningContent topics with the module components (lessons).

conbody.section:
Assessment structure
Assessments (test questions) come after the learning content in each module and use a <topichead> for the assessment title, as shown in bold:<map> <title>Basic DITA</title> <topicmeta> <critdates> <created date="2015-04-23"/> </critdates> </topicmeta> <topicref href="topics/lc_dita_intro.dita"> <topicref href="topics/lc_markup.dita"/> <topicref href="topics/lc_structure.dita"/> <topicref href="topics/lc_topic.dita"/>
<topichead navtitle="Assessments"> <topicref href="assessments/lca_validtopic.dita"/> <topicref href="assessments/lca_topicscope.dita"/> ... </topichead> </topicref>
...
</map>
Each assessment question goes into its own learningAssessment topic. Do not include title text in assessment topics. Each assessment requires a unique ID for the question type (lcSingleSelect in the following sample). This is not the same as the ID of the learningAssessment topic itself. <learningAssessment id="assessment_htp_t21_wr"> <title></title> <prolog> <author>Sharon Burton</author> <author href="http://www.scriptorium.com">Sarah O'Keefe, Scriptorium</author> <critdates> <created date="2015-04-28"/> </critdates> </prolog> <learningAssessmentbody> <lcInteraction><lcSingleSelect id="topics3"> <lcQuestion>When creating a concept topic, you will often:</lcQuestion> <lcAnswerOptionGroup> ... </lcAnswerOptionGroup> </lcSingleSelect> </lcInteraction> </learningAssessmentbody> </learningAssessment>Make sure you do not overlap with other IDs in the modules. Consider a unique ID prefix for your learning assessment content (for example, your initials or something related to the content you are developing).

section.title: File structure and naming conventions
section.p:
The DITA training project is divided into subfolders:
topics: for most content
assessments: for quizzes, test, and other assessment content
media; for images, videos, and other non-text content
Map files and general project information go at the root level. We recommend creating a map file for each module.

Use the following file name prefixes:
m_ for map files
lc_ for learning content
lca_ for learning assessments

section.title: Standards for images and video
section.p: As a general rule, use web-friendly formats, such as PNG or GIF for images. The easiest way to provide videos is to post them on YouTube and link to the YouTube video using the object tag.
